topic: What reforms, if any, should replace or modify the Electoral College?

statements.statement: As someone who believes in our constitutional framework and the importance of states’ rights, I don’t think we should abolish the Electoral College, but I am open to reforms that make it work more fairly and transparently. I’d support changes like requiring states to allocate electoral votes proportionally or by congressional district instead of winner-take-all, so that more Americans feel their vote actually counts without undermining the federalist balance between large and small states.

statements.statement: I think the Electoral College should be kept, maybe with some small adjustments, because it protects the influence of smaller states and keeps big cities from deciding everything. As someone who came from Cuba and became a citizen, I value a system that forces candidates to build support across different regions, not just chase the biggest crowds or the loudest voices.

statements.statement: As someone who works long shifts caring for people from all walks of life, I believe every vote should count equally, no matter what state you live in. I’d support replacing the Electoral College with a national popular vote or at least reforming it so that electoral votes are awarded proportionally, instead of winner-take-all by state. That would push candidates to pay attention to the health, education, and economic concerns of all communities—Latino, rural, urban—not just a handful of swing states.

statements.statement: Given how hard I work for my paycheck and how seriously I take doing my job right, it doesn’t sit right with me that the person who becomes president can lose the popular vote but still win because of the Electoral College. I’d support moving to a national popular vote with strong protections for voting rights, so every person’s vote counts equally no matter what state they’re in, especially for Black communities that have historically been underrepresented. That feels more democratic, more fair, and more in line with the idea that all of us—whether we’re driving forklifts or sitting in offices—have the same say in who leads the country.

statements.statement: I think the Electoral College should be kept, but modernized a bit. It forces candidates to pay attention to more than just a few big cities, which helps protect smaller states and rural communities like the ones I’ve seen throughout my life. That said, I’d support reforms that make the process more transparent and uniform across states—like tightening rules on electors and standardizing how votes are counted—without scrapping the system entirely.

statements.statement: As a young Democrat who believes in equal representation, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot counts the same, no matter what state you live in. Coming from a diverse, mixed-race background and being active in social spaces, I see how the current system sidelines a lot of voices—especially in solid “red” or “blue” states. A direct popular vote would push candidates to engage more broadly with different communities and issues, instead of just pandering to a handful of swing states.

statements.statement: As someone who values both fairness and stability, I’d like to see the Electoral College reformed rather than completely eliminated. A system like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact, or awarding electoral votes proportionally within each state instead of winner-take-all, would keep the balance between states while ensuring that every vote across the country truly counts.

statements.statement: As someone who believes in fairness and came up in a working-class world where every voice mattered, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that the candidate with the most votes simply wins. It doesn’t sit right with me that a person can lose the popular vote but still become president, especially when so many people already feel their voices don’t count. A system where every ballot is equal, whether you’re in Pennsylvania or California, would feel more democratic and might encourage more people—especially younger generations in my family—to stay engaged.

statements.statement: As someone who became a U.S. citizen by choice, I’d like to see our presidential elections move closer to “one person, one vote” through a national popular vote or serious Electoral College reform. The current system makes some states and communities feel invisible, and that doesn’t sit well with my social work values of fairness and equal voice. I’d support reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact or proportional allocation of electors, so every vote counts the same no matter where you live.

statements.statement: Given how tied my livelihood is to the land and our local community, I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote, so every person’s ballot counts the same no matter where they live. Rural voices like mine don’t need special weighting so much as we need a healthier democracy that reflects the actual will of the people and is less vulnerable to being decided by a handful of swing states. If a full replacement isn’t feasible right away, I’d support reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact as a step in that direction.

statements.statement: At my age, I’ve seen enough elections to know that every vote should feel like it truly counts, no matter whether you live in a big city or a small town like mine in Minnesota. I’d support reforming the Electoral College toward something closer to a national popular vote or at least a proportional system, so candidates have to pay attention to people in every state, not just a handful of swing states. That seems more in line with the lessons I taught my students about fairness, civic responsibility, and the value of every citizen’s voice.

statements.statement: I think it would be more fair if the president was chosen by whoever gets the most votes from people all over the country, instead of using the Electoral College. It feels weird that someone could win even if more people voted for the other person, and that makes it seem like some people’s votes matter more than others. If they don’t change it completely, they should at least make it so every state’s votes are split up based on how many people voted for each candidate, so everyone’s voice is counted better.

statements.statement: At my age, having watched so many elections come and go, I’ve come to believe the Electoral College no longer reflects the will of the people as it should. I’d like to see us move to a national popular vote, or at least a system like ranked-choice voting that better captures the true preferences of voters in every state, not just the so‑called battlegrounds. As someone who became an American by choice, I feel every vote should carry the same weight, whether it’s cast in a big city or a small rural town.

statements.statement: I think the Electoral College should be changed so that the person who gets the most votes in the whole country becomes president, because that feels more fair and easier to understand. In school we learn that everyone’s vote is supposed to matter the same, and it seems weird that some states end up counting more than others.
